posts.cooked: Hello everyone! My team is trying to switch over from a REV drivetrain to a fully CTRE one with Krakens currently and are having trouble with the heading with the Pigeon 2. Initially after using our zeroHeading() method, (line 433) our robot will drive in the correct direction. However, after our robot turns 180, the wheels drive at an angle rather than forward when we go forward. Is there something we did wrong in the zeroHeading() method? Here’s our code repository.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
@bhall-ctre to provide a bit of context what we are trying to achieve with those custom heading methods is similar to the question asked at Properly Setting Gyro Yaw when Robot is being placed on the field

We simply want to set a forward direction independently of where the robot is pointing at when placed on the field (which may or may not be a real field). With code based on the MAXSwerve template and a NavX gyro we were simply forcing the direction of the gyro to match what we wanted, so we initially tried to go for the same approach with the CTRE generated swerve code, but we don’t really need to interact with the gyro if it’s problematic.

We have assumed that a reset followed by a taring would be appropriate, but at this point we are wondering if it’s indeed okay.

In short, we are clueless and are hoping you can enlighten us as the best approach to fulfill our needs using your system. Thanks!

link_counts.title: Properly Setting Gyro Yaw when Robot is being placed on the field

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: Not from CTRE , but here’s how I do this on my team: To set a pose on the field, use SwerveDrivetrain.resetPose(Pose2d) . This also resets the gyro to the angle you tell it without anything else necessary. To set the “forward direction” (i.e. the field-relative direction that the robot thinks forwards is), use the method SwerveDrivetrain.setOperatorPerspectiveForward(Rotation2d) .

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thank you!

If we want the forward direction to be the default (i.e. towards the opposing alliance, would calling resetPose() be enough or does resetPose() have an impact on the forward direction that needs to be corrected?)

What is your understanding of seedFieldCentric() compared to resetPose()?

Also, do you have a public code example that we could look at?

posts.name: Gina W
posts.cooked: For more context/understanding of our situation, heres a video of our drivetrain (Robot is supposedly only going forward and backward here): https://youtu.be/OgQqy80djuQ?si=ZPojjXuoEMIV-raI

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
With CTRE , the operator forward direction is field relative, so it isn’t affected by the robot’s rotation.

Let’s say you’re on the blue alliance. You position you robot on the starting location, facing the blue alliance driver station (i.e. a field-relative rotation of 180degrees). Calling resetPose() with the correct position (with a rotation of 180 degrees) will tell the robot where it is. Therefore, the robot’s estimated field-relative pose will line up with its real field-relative pose.

From there, let’s say that you drive in teleop using a SwerveRequest.FieldCentric request. By default, it uses whatever the drivetrain’s operator forward perspective is. In the codebase provided by the original poster, the code to set the forward direction is automatically generated by CTRE , and it’s on CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java , line 275. This means that applying that request with velocity of (x: 1, y: 1) will cause the robot to move (from the field’s point of view) one meter per second away from the blue alliance wall (positive x), and one meter per second in the positive y direction, from the field’s point of view.

Adding nonzero operator forward directions can cause different behavior. For example, we have a button on our controller that resets the operator forward direction to the robot’s current field-relative orientation. The end result of this is that telling the robot to travel with an x velocity of 1 and y velocity of 0 causes the robot to travel in the direction that it was facing when we applied the new operator forward direction . Even if the robot rotates as it drives, it will always treat +x as in the direction of the operator forwards perspective , from a global, field-relative POV.

As for seedFieldRelative() , the docs say the following:

This is equivalent to calling resetRotation(Rotation2d) with the operator perspective rotation.

So what this does is tells the robot “you’re now facing away from the blue alliance”. The robot says “okay” and then resets its odometry to match. If you’re in a match and you give it the wrong angle, this can make the robot very confused because all of its pose estimation (besides vision) comes from the robot-relative chassis speeds. To turn robot-relative chassis speeds into field-relative chassis speeds, you need an accurate measure of the robot’s field relative orientation.

All of what I’m saying is used in our codebase here .

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thank you. Everything is clear except that paragraph:

therekrab:

If you’re in a match and you give it the wrong angle, this can make the robot very confused because all of its pose estimation (besides vision) comes from the robot-relative chassis speeds. To turn robot-relative chassis speeds into field-relative chassis speeds, you need an accurate measure of the robot’s field relative orientation.

Assuming no vision is involved to simplify the scenario, while the estimated field-relative pose would obviously not align with the real field-relative pose anymore, why would the robot be very confused?

And did you get a chance to look at the video? If the initial pose is correct, why would the robot lose track of where forward is when it spins on itself?

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Sorry, I definitely should have elaborated on this more. To compensate, here’s a big block of text:

Basically this comes down to how field-relative position is calculated. Without vision, we can’t directly measure where we are. But we can measure what direction we’re moving in. By accumulating (integrating) our velocity, we can see how far we’ve moved. A little bit of an oversimplification, but this gets the point across: Each tick, the robot measures it’s robot relative velocity in the x and y direction. It then turns this into field-relative velocities by “unrotating” by the robot’s measured angle. Then, it mutliplies this rate of change (meters per second) by the time difference (something like 0.02 seconds) to get a net change in position. So the new position = old position + delta position.

The big deal here is that your robot needs an accurate field-relative rotation to “unrotate” the robot-relative chassis speeds to get field-relative speeds. If the rotation goes wrong, then the robot will think it’s going one way when it’s actually going another. This means that even if the pose was correct in terms of X and Y initially (but wrong in rotation), over time, the estimated pose will lose accuracy because it moves in a different direction. I said “confused” because it could misbehave later, if you ever use field-relative position to make decisions. It was more of an aside to be aware than anything else, sorry about the confustion. LMK if I didn’t explain that well.

gartaud:

And did you get a chance to look at the video?

I did take a look at the video. I wasn’t sure exactly what the driver was doing, which made it a little tricky to debug, but I think I got the gist. Here’s what I noticed:

When the video started, the robot was facing some angle. If this is when the heading reset occurred, then this would now be the “forward” direction. Later, after turning, the voice in the video said “drive forward” and the robot proceeded to travel in the same direction it was initially facing. This supports the idea that the heading reset occurred when the robot was facing in that direction.

But I’m definitely missing something, because if I was right that would be expected behavior (it remembers forwards) and there wouldn’t be a problem. TL;DR: I got a little confused watching the video, because I wasn’t sure exactly when the heading reset occurred nor could I see the driver inputs.

If I had to guess what was going on, I’d probably think that it could be some strange issue with the reset heading method. I downloaded your codebase and ran it in simulation, and even while rotating, the “forward direction” was preserved. I’ve still yet to test the heading reset command, but initially at least, without running that, I see behavior I’d expect.

If I had to propose a solution, it would just be to use the builtin abstractions CTRE provides - operator forward perspectives and the resetPose() and resetRotation() methods to set the “field-relative” rotations. If everything else seems to be working, I guess the next step could be to watch the estimated pose on SmartDashboard. If there’s a problem with the gryo, then it should show up as either nor rotating enough or rotating too far, which could make the robot lose track of the right orientation. Even if the gyro is reporting correctly, I suspect that watching the pose on the dashboard may clue us into the real issue here.

The simplest test that I could think of running would be to do the following:

Call resetRotation(Rotation2d.kZero) to tell the robot it’s currently facing away from the blue alliance.

Call setOperatorPerspectiveForward(Rotation2d.kZero) to tell the robot to travel in the field-relative direction of 0 degrees.

Driving the robot should be relative to the robot’s position now , and rotations in the future shouldn’t affect which way is forwards.

One more thing: your zeroHeading() method calls the resetRotation(180deg) last, so the robot’s forwards direction will probably be backwards, and vice versa. I assumed this was intentional, but I wanted to verify.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thank you again.

I sadly wasn’t able to get there to observe in person, but trying to summarize what I was told, I understand it as the chess equivalent of a rook becoming a bishop when the rook is turned around.

We will send more info to the dash next week to see if the gyro angle and the pose stay in synch or not.

oppositeHeading() indeed rotates by 180deg. The use case is when the robot is placed on the field looking at the driver (as in the 2024 season).

Have a great weekend!

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
therekrab:

So what this does is tells the robot “you’re now facing away from the blue alliance”.

More specifically, seedFieldCentric() tells the robot that it’s now facing in the direction of the Rotation2d that was provided to setOperatorPerspectiveForward() . The operator perspective should always be set to Rotation2d.kZero on the Blue Alliance and Rotation2d.k180deg on the Red Alliance, and seedFieldCentric() should be called after setting the operator perspective forward. Alternatively, resetRotation(Rotation2d) always takes a field-centric rotation (0 deg is away from blue, 180 deg is away from red).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: jweston
posts.cooked:
Are the module wheels all facing the same angle or are they at different angles?

I ask because, if it’s different angles, it could be that your module encoder magnets may need to be secured. If they are the same angle, it’s more likely to be an IMU thing.

The way to check if your module encoder magnets are drifting is to draw a sharpie line across the magnet extending to the edge of the magnet holder. Drive and spin the wheels and re-check the line. If the sharpie line on the magnet(s) don’t line up with the sharpie at the edge, you need to glue the magnet down to keep it from drifting. A tiny slice of stretched double-sided tape around the bottom does nicely.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks.

It appears that our issue was that calling reset() on the pigeon returns prior to the pigeon being completely reset and that tareEverything() was therefore called too early.

As we actually don’t need to reset the pigeon, we commented out those calls and everything is now working as expected.

We had somehow assumed that reset() without a timeout parameter would wait long enough for the reset to fully complete, but it seems that it was a misguided assumption?

posts.name: jweston
posts.cooked:
Yeah, the timing on some Pigeon calls can be a little tricky.

I’ve found it works best if you only reset() in a robot constructor or robot init and then call tareEverything() in an auto/teleop init/periodic.

reset() is non-blocking, so if you call tareEverything() immediately after calling reset(), the Pigeon will zero out it odometry values while the reset is still running.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
After competing off season today with our season’s mediocre robot converted just in time for this event to a full CTRE drivetrain (same MK4i swerve modules but Neo/Thrifty absolute encoders/NavX combo replaced by Kraken/CANcoders/Pigeon 2 combo on dedicated CANIvore bus), I wanted to let you know that we are extremely happy with your product. It just works.

We wish we had this system from the start. Thank you.
